text:
Q: How to dump specific data on SqlMap? A:

Dump data with specified file, I just ran this command:

--dump -D database -T table -C number, vorname, transfer

Q: Encrypting data to be stored in chrome storage A:

Encryption is the easy part, it can be done with any other API available to the web, like the Web Crypto API.

The issue is that there's no way to safely persist the encryption key or passcode locally. Alternatives include:

  • your own server-based authenticated API to remotely store and retrieve this key
  • have the user enter a passcode at some point and just keep it in memory (for example using the chrome.storage.session API), but lose it when the browser is closed.

These two methods are used by password managers and cryptocurrency wallets for example.

Q: How to automate versioning via CI in a Python project? A:

Personally I would do two things if you need to automate the version like this

  • don't automatically increment the major or minor versions, but fix them in a file like some version.py
  • use epoch time int(time.time()) or an ISO 8601-style datetime like 0.0.20251227024000
    • later builds will always have a higher version (time going backwards almost-always represents system misconfiguration and epoch will add a digit in about 260 years..)
    • makes it easy to find out when the build was created

However, for installing, I would skip over the version naming and install by-path, then you can ideally avoid the problem - build the package where you test it with each version of Python and dependencies you're testing with, installing them explicitly and your built package by-path, then report on the versions installed during the output (pip freeze)

Notably too, this approach allows you more flexibility test with specific dependencies, which can be extremely useful for injecting older versions you believe have a bug or interact badly with your library - it potentially also allows you to bring in builds from other CI runs more easily

python3 -m pip install -f requirements.txt
python3 -m build
python3 -m pip install --no-dependencies --force-reinstall ./dist/my-pkg-*.whl

Q: create database in server(truenas scale) A:

TrueNAS SCALE now natively supports Docker, starting from the 24.10 "Electric Eel" update.

This transition from Kubernetes makes running containers much lighter and more straightforward.

You can easily deploy a PostgreSQL container by using the "Custom App" feature in the Apps portal. Simply provide the PostgreSQL image name and define your environment variables, or use a Docker Compose file for more control. It is a highly efficient way to manage your database alongside your ZFS storage.

Youtube: A Better Way to Run Docker Apps on TrueNAS

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gPL7_tzsJO8
